name: vulgaris-conditiva
definition: Beetroot is one of the several cultivated varieties of beets family, grown for their edible taproots and their leaves.
description:
Beetroot is a herbaceous biennial vegetable, in the beets family, grown as annuals crops for their edible root.

The plant is usually erect with a long main root and a rosette of leaves growing on stems.

The leaves are oval in shape, arranged alternately on the stem and grow 20 to 40 centimeters in length.

The roots are usually red in color.

The plant produces sessile green flowers and can reach 1 to 2 meters in height.

Beets are usually grown as annual plants, harvested after one growing season.

Beetroot is a cosmopolitan crop plant probably originating in the Old World.

Assyrians were using beetroot in Hanging Gardens of Babylon 800 years BC.

Beetroot is cultivated mainly because of its high nutritional value.

Chemical compounds isolated from beetroot are used in medicine, chemical and food industry.

Beetroot juice is today advocated as a stimulant for the immune system and as a cancer preventative.

Besides being used as a food, beets have uses as a food colouring and as a medicinal plant.

Usually the deep purple roots of beets are eaten boiled, roasted, or raw, and either alone or combined with any salad vegetable.

A large proportion of the commercial production is processed into boiled and sterilized beets or into pickles.

In Eastern Europe, beet soup, such as borscht, is a popular dish.

In Indian cuisine, chopped, cooked, spiced beet is a common side dish.

The green, leafy portion of the beet is also edible.

The young leaves can be added raw to salads, whilst the mature leaves are most commonly served boiled or steamed.

Beetroots are cool season vegetables with a long growing season.

They grow best in cool climates but can tolerate some heat as well as some freezing.

The optimum temperature for their growth is between 15.5 and 18.3°C.

Beetroots grow best in a loose, well draining soil with a pH between 6.2 and 6.8 and should be planted in full sun for optimum development.

They will reach harvestable size of 3 to 8 centimeters in diameter between 40 and 80 days after sowing.

Wild sea beet is the ancestor of all cultivated beets including beetroot.

It grows in coastal areas in Europe, North Africa and Asia.

The leaves of sea beet have probably been consumed since prehistoric times in Europe.

contextual.caption: Beetroots are mainly grown for their swollen, bulb-shaped, usually red in color, root but also for their leaves.

featured.caption: Beetroot plant is usually erect with a long main root and a rosette of oval leaves growing on stems.

facts.name: Purple color given by betain
facts.value: Betain is a substance isolated from beetroot. It is responsible for the purple color of the root. This substance is used in food industry to improve color and taste of desserts, jams, ice-creams, jellies, tomato sauces and breakfast cereals.

facts.name: Cultivated mainly for its edible root
facts.value: Most people cultivate beetroot because of its edible root. It develops 55 to 65 days after planting of seed. Root is usually red to purple in color. Unlike other types of vegetables, root contains high quantities of sugar.

facts.name: Can be used raw, cooked or pickled
facts.value: Beetroot can be used raw, cooked or pickled. It is often used for salads, soups and as an ingredient of dishes made of meat. Beetroot can be also used for the manufacture of wine.

facts.name: Leaves are also edible
facts.value: Leaves of beetroot are also edible. Fresh leaves taste like spinach.

facts.name: Leaves were used for binding of wounds
facts.value: Leaves of beetroot were used for binding of wounds in the ancient Greece. Beetroot was popular "mouth freshener" in the past. It was used to eliminate the smell of garlic. Latest medical experiments showed that beetroot lowers blood pressure and increases endurance in athletes. It also prevents development of liver diseases which result from protein deficiency, diabetes or alcohol abuse.

facts.name: Beetroot juice was used as dye
facts.value: Beetroot juice was used as dye in the past. During the 19th century, women used beetroot for dyeing of hair.

facts.name: Popular aphrodisiac in Roman times
facts.value: Beetroot contains high amount of boron which facilitates production of sex hormones. It was popular aphrodisiac during the Roman time.

facts.name: Stems can grow up to 198 centimeters
facts.value: Beetroot develops leafy stem that can grow 100 to 198 centimeters in height.

facts.name: Small, green or reddish flowers
facts.value: Beetroot develops small, green or reddish flowers that appear in dense spikes. Flowers are pollinated by wind.

facts.name: Heart-shaped leaves
facts.value: Beetroot has heart-shaped leaves. They are usually 2 to 8 inches long in wild plants and much longer in cultivated varieties.

facts.name: Lotion for dundruff removal
facts.value: Home-made lotion (produced by boiling the beetroot) can be used for the removal of dandruff.

facts.name: Fruit of beetroot is called nutlet
facts.value: Fruit of beetroot is called nutlet. It has hard structure and it is arranged in clusters.

facts.name: High nutritional value
facts.value: Beetroot has high nutritional value. Besides high content of sugar, beetroot is rich source of vitamins B6 and B9 and minerals such as iron, magnesium and potassium.

facts.name: Beetroot juice can determine acidity
facts.value: Juice made of beetroot can be used instead of litmus paper to determine acidity or alkalinity of solution. One drop of beetroot juice changes its color in pink in acid solutions and into yellow in alkaline solution.

facts.name: Biennial plant
facts.value: Beetroot is biennial plant which means that it finishes its life cycle in two years.
